Hi Mike,

> For some forms of metadata, you want the authoritative source to be the
> resource itself - like what the allowed programmatic interactions are.

If I understand you correctly, you are saying that a Web service should
have an "authoritative service description".  I agree!  The
Meta-Location header provides the URL to the service's authoritative
service description.

> Other
> metadata, like making claims 'about' the resource (asserting that it is a
> member of some topic/subject/concept/etc.) benefits from being external and
> having multiple sources to varying trust.

It's more than that. Suppose that my shop is running RDF engines to
enable inductive reasoning, and suppose that the Web service that my
company wants to use just provides an XHTML description.  Thus, my
company creates an RDF description of the Web service - it tells the HOW
of how the use it, and it does it using RDF.  Thus, my company's RDF
description adds value to the Web service, and it does it in a
distributed fashion. /Roger
